column6: Edy and Josh are the BEST bartenders. We had a great time, drinks were amazing! Have gone twice now and will definitely be back
Good food, good service and good vibe. Drinks have some Chinese twists. Highly recommend!

column3: Lower East Side, New York, NY
column6: Food is great! I like how they present traditional chinese food in a new way! Highly recommend

Cool vibes/decor and great drinks! I opted for the bird's nest since the bartender said it tastes the least like alcohol compared to everything else on the whole menu lol. It was pretty good and very sweet, not one of the best drinks I've had but in general I liked how creative the drink menu was! Especially as a Chinese American recognizing a bunch of cultural references in the drink names, and the unique Chinese ingredients that are mixed into the drinks. In terms of food, I liked the truffle mushroom salad the most bc the flavors were on point. Pork belly was okay to me, I felt like the portions were way too small and could have been more tender. Crab fried rice was solid though!

Sooo yummy! Absolutely loved this place and want to come back soon. We order 3 things for the table: the duck salad, vegetable fried rice, and the short ribs. All were amazing and packed with flavor. The kale in the salad is kept crispy, I have no idea how they do that but it's such a great pairing with the duck. The vegetable fried rice may *sound* plain, but it definitely isn't. It's super fragrant and is the perfect carb-y dish to go with any of the mains! The short rib sat on a creamy coconut curry sauce and came with a small side of crispy rice on the plate. The short rib was insanely tender and the meat fell right off the bone. Everything was delicious and this is easily at the top of my favorite Thai spots in the city now.

found a new lunch spot in soho!!! So goodddd southern curry over rice is my favorite. So rich and spicy . Tom Yum noodle soup is very authentic as well. Well I love spicy when they hit the spot I definitely recommend. Service is always attentive and friendly. Now I found a new spot to hang in soho. Love WanWan

When I saw that Erika Chou, owner of Wayla and Kimika, was opening a Thai restaurant, I had to make a reservation! It claims to be "Old-Phuket style," blending local Thai and immigrant Chinese cooking, which resulted in delicious flavors I had never had before. The restaurant has a cozy upscale vibe, with gorgeous art deco chandeliers and velvet pillowed seating. We ordered the marinated spare ribs, duck salad, crab curry noodles, and wagyu thin rice noodles. All the dishes had complex, well-balanced flavors, but were on the smaller portion and pricier side. The crab curry was so rich and tasty, but much spicier than I expected - it was a masochistic experience where I was crying but couldn't stop myself from taking more bites. The coconut rice pudding was a refreshing dessert to finish off the meal. TL;DR don't come here expecting typical Thai food, come here for an experience!
We came here for drinks and it was awesome!! The pandan colada and Tom Numb were really unique and delicious drinks! The food looked amazing so I definitely want to come back and try it

Amazing newcomer to the area! Mood lighting, yummy cocktails, and delicious well priced noodz. Lovely experience here. The food came out quickly and the menu consists of elevated takes on classic favorites plus some that are more difficult to find at your basic pad thai place (there's no pad thai on the menu). The appetizers were fantastic--shrimp tempura, short ribs and beef steamed buns were fantastic starters for our mains--the pad kee mao and beef broth noodles were great for a cold day, as was the ba mee pu moo yang (worth memorizing the name for), which has amazingly springy yellow noodles and comes with a side of broth to ease the chill of nyc winter.

Literally the best Thai food I have ever tasted in my entire life!!!! I got the pad kee mao and it was DELICIOUS!!! It had the perfect amount of spice and everything just tasted so FRESH. The basil it was topped with was so crunchy. If I lived closer, I would have already gone back. However, when I'm in the area, I'll definitely stop by!! I recommend wan wan for sure!!!

Having been to Wayla, I had a pretty good idea of what the vibe might be here, but this spot actually surpassed my expectations. Food was incredible and perfectly spicy. Saw Chinese Thai fusion dishes that I've never heard of before too which is always exciting! Good atmosphere and decor as well. Because it's a newer restaurant, it was easy to snag a res, but I imagine that soon this place will be packed every night.
Came here with family to try. Everything was either too sweet or salty. Appetizer were okay. But the entree were where it failed. Never coming back here.

Came here for dinner on a Sunday and I felt everything was subpar. We got fried pork belly, spare ribs, steamed branzino, and duck broth and nothing to write home about. However, we all enjoyed our drinks and it was happy hour at the time which was a nice surprise - $4 off all of our cocktails
Not sure what the hype is for thai diner bc this place is way better and closeby! Creative flavorful dishes, good vibe, great /friendly service, boozy cocktails with thai ingredients

Came with a friend to grab dinner on a rainy day. The place is pretty spacious so getting a table wasn't too hard. They're still waiting on the liquor license so they only had non alcoholic drinks available. We tried the duck salad, fried pork belly, and the Guay Tiew Kua Gai (rice noodle with chicken). Overall, the felt like the food was okay, but the flavors and textures were a bit unexpected and didn't really work well together. The fried pork belly was heavy and a bit dry. The rice noodle and duck salad both had baked/fried kale that add a strange texture into the dishes. The chicken in the noodle dish was cooked nicely but the noodle to chicken ratio was off. We would have liked more noodles for a noodle dish.

My favorite from this visit at @wanwan.nyc was definitely the crab cakes! They were super rich with the curry flavor, and brought me memories of my vacations in Thailand I personally liked it more straight up, but it was also really good with the pineapple sauce! A little bummed that the pot pie was sold out (at 1pm lol) so we didn't get to try it, because the pictures looked good~
Some of the best Thai food I've had! I love pad kee mao and theirs is incredible. The service was polite and friendly, and the ambiance was lovely. Highly recommend.

Have been enjoying dinner at Wan Wan a few times a month now, and it's even better than brunch! Service is great, and the dishes are super flavorful and unique. Highly recommend the Guay Tiew Kay Gai -- super tasty

Recently visited Wan Wan. The food was excellent! Specifically, the Pad Kee Mao and Guay Tiew Nua. My friend and I both really enjoyed it. The staff was also lovely. We needed an accommodation, and they were understanding and helpful. Our server made great recommendations as well! Very cute spot, highly recommend!

Happened upon this spot with some friends and they were able to seat us quickly-- I think we went during their soft launch. All the dishes were excellent, with a wonderful blend of textures to keep the mouth entertained. Pricing seemed reasonable and I'd definitley go back. Worth noting, when we went they did not serve any alcohol.
This is their best lower Manhattan restaurant I've been to in a long time! Unique menu, executed perfectly! Can't wait to come again , it is so worth it!
We had Lobster noodle, shrimp fried rice and duck spring roll. The lobster was over cooked. Fried rice was mushy. The duck spring roll was tasty and the only thing that we liked.

Before I get into the food, the service here is very cognizant and sensitive to gluten allergies. Many great dishes if you have a gluten allergy. Now the food did not disappoint. Everything from small plates to entrees was delicious. I suspect that their place will get booked in the future as more people hear about it. They are expanding downstairs too where you can host private parties.

Perfect! Food, service, cocktails, ambiance ... absolutely perfect. We tried every cocktail, quite a few appetizers, dinners... everything was paced well, spiced to perfection. Cozy cool perfect dining experience.

Visited wan wan today for brunch which I believe they just started. First of, SUPER cute restaurant. Very chill vibes and great decor, perfect for brunch with friends. Brunch menu is different than dinner menu so make sure you check before going in case you wanted to try the lobster tomyum noodles or wagyu soup noodles (those are dinner only). The appetizers were really good, especially the duck salad - outstanding. 5/5. The pork belly was pretty good too and taste rather authentic. The massaman curry pot pie was also outstanding - good combo of French/Thai. The nam prik noodles was a meh for me but my friend loved it so either hit or miss. The rice clay pot was probably our least favorite. The rice was too dry and the meat lacked seasoning. Overall would recommend stopping by if you're feeling up for Thai fusion food for brunch!

Not worth the time and expense. I thought I would just try this place but I am not sure Nikita needs another expensive Thai place. Thai diner is sufficient and the food is very authentic. I would walk one block away and eat there instead.
Food was very good but service was lacking. I did not get the dish that I ordered and the waitress insisted that I did.
Cute restaurant with authentic Thai dishes. Ordered the duck noodles with chicken skin. Would recommend for a casual dinner catching up with a friend.
LOVE!!! Everything we ordered was amazing, especially the crispy chicken skin. Will def be coming back!

While I'd like to say this place is great (because the food is). I had a BAD experience here. For starters I booked a table in the basement, I was told my table wasn't ready yet so they sat me at the bar (it was after my reservation time). After ordering at the bar I was brought to an upstairs table. With every gust of wind we were hit with freezing air. Our drinks were brought up from the bar downstairs after we had to ask again where they were and one was wrong. We had to track down our waiter for everything and he was too busy to assist us. Our meal was almost two hours and we desperately were ready to go.

From the good folks that brought you Wayla, Wan Wan does NOT disappoint. Service was impeccable and oh, the flavors, all the dishes were so simple yet complex at the same time. For starters we got the Moo tod nam pla (pork belly), taw hu tod (fried tofu), and ped krob salad (crispy duck salad). Just wow...you can't fail with any of these. Pork belly is obvs a no-brainer, the fried tofu was coated with almost a mochi-like exterior which was very unique and worked so well, and whoever thought to add crispy kale chips in that duck salad is a genius. The Guay tiew nua (wagyu beef noodle soup) had some of the tenderest slices of beef I've ever had, and the broth was just divine. Make sure to leave room for the pandan coconut pudding dessert, because I would eat that every day if I could. Wan wan if you're reading this, PLEASE sell this dessert for takeout because I will legit come by every day *please*

Enjoyed a meal with a friend here recently, where we sampled a couple small dishes and a noodle dish. The tofu had a sticky/gooey quality to it which was pretty cool, though I think the peanut sauce could have been a little more flavorful or maybe I just needed more of it in general. The ribs were really great, sitting in a delicious sauce, and actually fairly easy to eat, tender and not too many bones. The crispy pork belly was good but I was expecting bigger pieces. On the other hand, the small pieces allowed for more chili sauce to pork belly bite ratio which was worthwhile. Finally we had the noodles with roast chicken, which I was hesitant about since I rarely order chicken dishes at restaurants, but the chicken skin here was so crispy and good, and the rest of the flavors and vegetables in the noodles were quite good together. Overall pretty solid food, great service, and with no liquor license yet, the bill stays pretty low!
Super duper delicious. Complex, rich, deep flavors. The curry was kick-you-in-the-face spicy. Didn't have anything that I thought was less than a 10/10. I can't wait to return.

Really nice intimate spot for dinner with kind servers who provided great recommendations for dishes. The Guay Tiew Kua Gai (9/10) and fried tofu (8/10) were our favorites. Crispy chicken skin tasted burnt (5/10) and fish dish with broccolini was small and lacking flavor (4/10).
LOVE. Every dish we got was incredible. Particularly recommend the Guay Tiew Kua Gai dish.

Not worth a visit for Thai food. Limited menu; mostly fried food that looks like it came out of a Trader Joe's frozen dinner box; and a mostly noodle centric main course menu that is not authentically "Thai." Seasoning didn't "pop" like Thai food is supposed to do when it hits your tongue. Menu super small. No liquor license. They don't permit BYOB either. A total "miss" for Thai cuisine. Two starts because they were nice but the kitchen is a rudderless ship.
Food was excellent and authentic. Portions were small so you can try many different dishes. Service was great. Highly recommend.

Absolutely loved the overall dining experience here at Wan Wan! Everything from the food, the decor, the staff was excellent. Also, the location couldn't be better with it being so centrally located in the center of trendy Nolita. I felt the food was very authentic and the menu had a great selection of dishes you don't see at your basic Thai restaurant. I would highly recommend Wan Wan!

Karasu is a Japanese speakeasy hidden behind a secret door inside Walter's, and has been my go-to for special occasions since before the pandemic. Their art deco interior paired with dimly lit private tables create a sexy, intimate atmosphere - especially as you sip on their unique twists on classic cocktails. Order the Koji Ribeye, for sure!!! I've been to my fair share of Japanese steakhouses, and this cut was seasoned and cooked to PERFECTION. Always one of the most memorable dishes that come to mind when friends or coworkers ask for restaurant recommendations. Definitely worth the drive out from Queens or Long Island, I will continue coming for as long as they remain open.

Great experience. Extremely attentive and one of the best bartenders ever! She explained the cocktails and food and didn't rush us. Nonjudgmental  like many of the pretentious restaurants. Food was flavorful and simple in a good way. Excellent ingredients.

Everything we got was delicious and felt special (hamachi, Tuna, yaki imo, oysters). The oysters were particularly memorable- we contemplated getting a second order! Sat at the gorgeous bar, the whole place has a very sexy vibe and would be a perfect date spot.
Amazing service here. The host/waitress even moved our table to the best seat in the house when finding out it was for an anniversary. She was so kind and the food was amazing!

Absolutely one of my favorite dining experiences. We had to order seconds of some of the dishes because they were that good. This IS the first date restaurant you've been looking for. Make reservations for a friday or saturday, the atmosphere is perfect.

Excellent dinner with top notch service. Tuna and himachi apps with ribeye for two and a chocolate banana bread pudding. All so amazing. And the server helped us choose the perfect sake. We will definitely be back.

Karasu is a hidden gem located behind a secret door of Walter's, in the Fort Greene area of Brooklyn. Once inside you will find a beautiful and well designed space which includes a elegant bar and table seating. Food, service, and atmosphere are all top notch here. Tables were consistently full so you may want to book a reservation if you are dining during peak hours. Highlights of the meal for me included fresh oysters, duck wings, lobster pasta, and a perfectly cooked and seasoned rib eye. Come and dine at Karasu before the secret gets out!

Amazing little gem. Happened to stumble upon while strolling around the neighborhood and killing time to wait for a nearby restaurants seats. This place literally beat the other restaurant (which was also good, but this was even more memorable). A spontaneous find with my girlfriend and lots of dishes we both enjoyed. The steak is to die for - the best.

Tonight I learned that you primarily go here for the cocktails. I wanted a family style meal and if I wanted to get one I might as well have just gone to Walter's. Not that this place is bad, just really come here for the cocktails and expect it to not be cheap.
Hidden Japanese food joint in Walter's...great food, great drinks, intimate, and beautiful.

Didn't expect it but, Karasu was simply extremely good. It's kind of the place to go in this area. The menu is really awesome, a lot of fantastic choices, I had to go with Tonkatsu, and it was incredible. Staff is really pleasant and definitely will help you with everything. Everything was excellent at Karasu.

I used to love this spot, but never again. Its gone down hill pretty quickly. Host team ignored reservation notes and had no interest in accommodating anyone with the attitude to match. They even made a guest on crutches stand to wait for her table!  Food was hot trash. The edamame was overcooked to mush and the clams were a pitiful value. It was so bad we cut our visit short and went up the street to 1 Or 8.

Delicious food and cocktails but I'm still not sure it was worth the price tag. We prefer Walter foods/Walters. My fiancé left hungry, which is no burnout after throwing down a couple hundred dollars for dinner. I thought someone might have wished us congratulations also, as we were celebrating our engagement, but they did not.
Delicious!!! If you like meat, I recommend the prime rib or else the smell of someone else's prime rib will invariably make you regret missing out on that. Drinks are very nice here.

Awful experience at this restaurant. We (a group of 3) arrived at the restaurant on Friday night and were told there was an hour-long wait. We left a phone number, but noticed, after over an hour of waiting, that no one called us. We went back to the restaurant and asked the manager when we should expect to be seated, given that we had been waiting for over an hour. The manager snapped at us, despite having treated him with calm and respect, and used a disrespectful, irritated, and condescending tone to indicate that we should not be expecting a table. We decided not to wait any further and left the restaurant disappointed at the dismal service and awful attitude.

We had delicious food and an excellent waiter. Four of us had a great mix of the tapas. The gazpacho is a definite get, as is the Lobster and Scallop. The mackerel was perfect, with salted crispy skin being a highlight. The chefs really understand the delicate balance of flavour, texture, smell and visual, and are able to craft a full sensorial pleasure.

This hidden spot in the back of Walter's has a great, romantic atmosphere. Service was also really solid, as was the tremendous sake selection. The food was underwhelming for the most part and very overpriced. The only dish we loved was the fried chicken appetizer. The rest was pretty bland - especially the udon main dish which cost $20 and the clam appetizer for $15. Nothing seemed to have any salt or seasoning. Portions are also quite small.

Watching an episode of Chef's Night Out brought us here, and we were not disappointed.  I dig that this place is sort of like a speakeasy, where the restaurant is located behind a backdoor within another restaurant.  The look of the place is very cozy and you feel enrobed within some secret society where they serve impressively delicious Japanese food that comes out of an even more impressively tiny kitchen.  We didn't have reservations on a weeknight, but we were lucky enough to score two seats at the bar.  We came for a snack, but ended up ordering about 4 or 5 dishes, that were all quite tasty.  The most memorable and my favorite item was their Karaage Chicken followed by the Pickled Vegetables Three Ways which was the perfect acidic balance to the fried chicken.  We also had the delicate egg custard, "Chawanmushi" but that took a little while to make.  My husband was surprised by the Crab Salad (red crab, tofu, mentaiko, served with gyoza wrapper chips) and really seemed to have enjoyed that above all else.  Me, I was going in on that amazing karaage chicken thigh!  They serve nice, large chunks, that were meaty and juicy, but not oily, and just scrumptious, and actually the best karaage I've ever had.  It would have been absolutely perfect with a warm bowl of rice.  And we washed down our little "snack" with a refreshing yuzu soda, and it was overall a really delicious meal.  I'd be thrilled to come back and try their infamous Koji Prime Ribeye, that looks hella dreamy based off all the photos posted here on Yelp.

If you've ever seen Inception, this is the restaurant version. A restaurant with in a restaurant?!?  That's what you have here. In the back of a traditional American restaurant called Walter's, you can walk towards the back where the restrooms are and you'll find a nondescript black door that seemingly leads to nowhere. Open that door and your instantly transported into a Japanese izakaya speakeasy restaurant.  The food is great, but the drinks are even better! I had some roasted asparagus and bamboo, raw octopus, and some tasty miso soup.  My drink had a tequila base, but sported touches of ginger and jasmine. This trendy spot is one that you should definitely check out!

Noted there's a birthday celebration and the servers just seem over the night. Never checked if we were good or how the food was. Knocking over a glass on the birthday person and casually saying sorry cause you feel forced and walking away. Hostess was amazing. Food was good. If you're going to wipe all around the table don't be one handed and lazy, pick up the glasses in the way which would've prevented knocking a glass on my lap. I really wanted to like this place.

This place is a sparkling gem of a restaurant! You will feel instantly transported the moment you walk through the black door at Walter's. Staff and service are impeccable, and the vibe is cozy but not crowded. Drinks are FANTASTIC - my fave was the Night Night (sort of like a spicy plum Manhattan), and served in adorable vintage glasses. The food was outstanding. We eat a lot for two people, so we got two small plates and two large plates and it was perfect: miso potato salad, duck karaage, handmade uni pasta and sizzling prime rib for two. Everything was bursting with flavor, and the duck had one of the most unique sauces I've tasted in a long time. We had room for desert and got a scoop of maple walnut ice cream and sage ice cream. My husband liked the maple walnut and I was in love with the sage, so there was something for everyone. Would definitely go back again and again!

This was our second time to Karasu. We're fans of the food and the atmosphere. But last night, the miso soup was pretty tasteless. The server wasn't particularly friendly and a dish (the Japanese sweet potatoes) came out cold. When we asked the host if they were supposed to be cold- especially seeing as they came in tin foil and had butter in the side, he sheepishly said no, then returned to apologize and ask if he could offer us something else as there were no more potatoes. We assumed, given the situation that this would be on the house, it was after all a small dish that they brought completely cold and had no more of. So it was surprising to see them still charge us for the replacement item which totaled 12 bucks. I didn't say anything, it just felt like bad style and generally like the place isn't nearly as classy as it tries to appear.

This speak easy style restaurant is very intimate. It's located through Walters, lit but candles and frequented by couples. The menu is designed for sharing. We started with the Sweet Potato (highly recommend), karaage (highly recommend), and the mushrooms (eh). For our main we had the steak for two which was cooked perfectly. Our whole meal was delicious but WILDLY overpriced. The night finished at $200.... I was so disappointed. This is a place for extremely special occasions. Like my death.
Shortly after sharing the Ribeye I came to the realization that I just had the best steak I've ever had. Returning to this spot is a no brainer.

Great place for drinks at night or a date. Almost has a speakeasy feel with the separate bar and entrance at the back of the bar. Apparently their kitchen closes sooner than the front bar which closed its kitchen at 1am. I'd recommend.

'Secret Sushi' is what my family and I call it.  It's in the back of Walters, and when you walk in, and go to the back door to enter Karasu, it feels as if you are quite important.  It's fun!  When you just walk in, the staff from Walters will usually say, "Oh!  So, a table for (2)"?  You will then say politely, "We're here to go to Karasu, the place in the back"!  Then nod your head in the direction of the back door.  They will then guide you to the back door and you will enter an entirely different restaurant, and it will feel like you are changing dimensions.  We ordered the rice balls, which were a little bland by itself, but with soy sauce, they were much tastier.  Inside the rice, there is salmon, which was a surprise as we thought it was tuna.  Next I got the miso soup, and it was refreshing - although I think they could have added more tofu.  For the main course, I received rice, (yes more rice), topped with sashimi, caviar, and corn.  The sashimi's texture was amazing, and the corn was crunchy.  As for the steak, it was perfectly cooked, tender and flavorful.  The only thing was that there was way too much fat.  It was kind of hard to eat.  But the taste made up for that.  I totally recommend this place for a special night out.

Drinks were great, karage and steak are excellent. Very cute and romantic setting with a speakeasy atmosphere. The salads were very impressive! It is Asian fusion, not quite authentic but dishes were very well prepared.
The Dippermouth was the best cocktail i've ever had. Beautiful interior design, awesome cocktail glasses...took me back to time spent in Japan!

Stopped by with a couple of friends. Reservations are a must. Drinks were delicious. I was looking for a vodka based drink and they were able to substitute the Gin for vodka in a drink called Bee Side which I highly recommend. We had some sashimi as well which was fresh and delicious. Try it out.
Great service and amazing food/drinks. I like the fact that it's very low key. I advise making reservations, tables go quickly.

Love the ambience of this place and the food was pretty tasty. Particularly the octopus and fried chicken. Not a big menu and more of a good spot for delicious drinks. We went on a Monday and it wasn't too busy yet service was pretty bad. Would go back for cocktails at the bar.
Great service, fantastic experience.  This hidden gem is a Brooklyn treasure - must come and find the hidden secrets this has the unlock
In the back of another restaurant, really set up the mood once you get in.  Good sake, tasty food.  Had a very pleasant evening.

This place was good - a little over-hyped. I don't think we'll be back just because of the fairly small menu and the servers were a bit weird to interact with and seemed more focused on up-selling us vs. just being normal/nice. We were running 10 minutes late and they made sure to let us know we only had the table for an hour and a half. This was a completely fine amount of time, but it just felt kind of tacky. I personally don't like to know they are booking the tables that close together - to the point where they have to let you know what time to leave. The ambiance was cool; perfect lighting and noise level (good for a date). I thought the food was really good, so if you're willing to overlook the other things mentioned I'd give them four stars. I had the whole fish, which was amazing IMO - paired with this delicious white wine they had by the glass. My bf had the ramen, but he thought it was lack laster in comparison to others he's had for half the price. We also had the pickled veggies & warm potato with sesame butter (yum!). It's worth trying if you're looking for a new experience in BK!

i'm a little relieved i moved away from this neighborhood right as Karasu opened b/c i'd be here all the time if i hadn't. the drinks are unique and well-mixed, the food is perfection and the space is beautiful. such a great spot!

Cocktails are solid. Food is good. Sashimi small dish was aaawesome.  Interior is Art Deco in a cool subtle kind of way. Lastly, I love when you can tell a waiter how hungry you are and they give a legit answer to if you have ordered the right amount of food. Our guy hit it spot on.  Nice experience.

Fantastic experience, from the food, to the service, to the decor. We had multiple apps (the fried chicken was so good we had to order a second batch), the octopus, oysters, edamame (best I've ever had - with a nice amount of salt), miso soup, then moved on to the whole fish and rib eye. And, the buttermilk ice cream, with just a hint of "tang," was delicious! We cleaned every plate! I would absolutely recommend this hidden gem and, as an out-of-towner, truly hope I get to return!
I still give this 5 stars, quality is still solid from when it's existence wasn't even advertised yet. Great cocktails and good sake menu. The Koji ribeye for two was right on the money.
This is a terrific hidden gem behind Walters- go thru Walters to the door in the rear. The food is the best Japanese I've had in Brooklyn maybe all of NYC. Truly a find. Romantic space too. eat up!
My new local! I love this place. The staff is so charming, the menu is delightful, and they serve champagne by the glass.

I have been to Karasu many times, have brought family here and have raved about it to friends.  I was a big fan and supporter.  I came here last night and was utterly disappointed.  We tried 2 new (to us) dishes - the shrimp and the crab salad.  The shrimp was basically boiled shrimp with little extra flavor - nothing special (for $19), do not get.  The crab salad was also disappointing - it was just small and the flavors were not there.  The fried chicken was definitely good (we have always loved the fried chicken here) but it did not melt in our mouths like times past.  The beloved ribeye, which we also usually rave about, was just not as good as previously - it was chewy in many parts and just did not meet expectations.  I am hoping this was just an off night but the quality of the food seems to have gone down considerably and I can no longer congratulate it.  Also a salmon starter dish that we loved before (I believe lightly seared and it also melted in your mouth) was off the menu - another disappointment and sweet potato jumped from $6 to $10!  I hope Karasu works harder to regain quality they had previously.
Fantastic ribeye (we've come back just for the beef), good cocktails, and interesting apps/sides.  Great vibe and mid-range prices.  Nice foodie-oriented wait staff.

Eh. Atmosphere is cute but food was severely underwhelming, and drinks didn't live up to the hype. And it's expensive! There were lots of bones in the sashimi (!), and everything else (octopus sunomono, seafood udon, pickled vegetables, mushrooms) was bland and portions were tiny. Wouldn't go back!

Unfortunately we were not impressed. We go out to eat a lot, I read an article couple of months ago, saw pretty good reviews her on Yelp and decided to take my husband here (he did not want to go). When we came in we were pretty excited, the place looks very intimate, however once we took a look at the menu we were turned off. Menu is very limited, prices are way too high. We have been to quiet a few Japanese restaurants and this is by far one of the worst. The edamame does not need a citrusy zest, the eggplant was not anything special just a poorly pickled vegg, we really wanted some raw fish (they just offered good old herring which I would only get at a Russian restaurant), and the dorado was somewhat decent. I honestly would never go back, I was quiet disappointed that my husband stayed pretty hungry after we left since nothing tastes good it was just ok. We were hungry so we had to eat. The scotch is very very overpriced. You do not have to pay$ 26 for a mediocre scotch and barely an ounce pour. Overall i would not go back and do not recommend to get the dishes we got. May be others like it but if you enjoy good Japanese go to Zuma!

Creative dishes, excellent service, and overall amazing experience. Karasu is one of the best hidden gems in NYC. Its versatile vibe is well suited to groups of friends or a romantic date. This is a fast favorite for thoughtful Japanese dishes that are perfectly paired with craft cocktails. Led by two brilliant chefs, Karasu is set to be a fixture in the global culinary scene.

Small place, but cozy ambiance. Great drinks, nice bar  nice staff, great food. Very small menu, but I have a weakness for tonkatsu and this is by far the best tonkatsu I've had in the US - maybe even in Japan because I didn't used to go to fancy restaurants there. The whole fish was also very good - maybe a tiny bit salty but done perfectly. Highly recommended.
Best Japanese curry in my opinion, they are consistent and quick. If you want a good meal, I would definitely recommend this chain restaurant.

Came here for chicken katsu curry. The sauce was delicious and sweet. The tempura and sausage adds additional flavour. The chicken is fragile and crispy. Recommend to eat slowly. Overall, the meal is fulfilling as one whole meal.

Great spot for a quick and delicious bite to eat. I love their katsu, enjoy their sauce, and always have a hard time deciding which of the many add-ons/options I want to enjoy. If you're hungry and in the area, stop by. And if you're hungry and not in the area, travel to a Go! Go! Curry! near you.

Food was tasty. I felt like the portions were fair for the price. Ill be honest and say it was good the best Japanese curry out there but was definitely good for fast food. Service was good. Nice staff. This location has a small dining area.

Great portion for the price. Curry dish we got was really good. The rice was well done. the fried Chicken meat slices were deliciously cooked. The curry was flavorful and wasnt too spicy at all. The space is small so order quickly. If you like Japanese Curry and youre in the area, try this place out
Super good.  Nothin fancy but worth to try . Dont miss this place near  Brooklyn bridge

Hey guys I will tell you about this place this is very nice wonderful please I have good experience about this this make me happy there is a family environment friendly environment all the employee for friendly and honest recommended all new user for this place ok thanks

Big portions and convenient! The shop is small but the selection is great. The portions are also very generous and lasts me 2 meals! The ration of curry to rice is also very good. My favorite is the chicken curry. I came in here on a rainy day after a long day out and just wanted something hot and filling. This place did not disappoint. It have decent katsu and the toppings are great

What can I say...Go Go Curry has always been my go-to spot for comfort food over the past several years.  There's no better pick-me-up after a long day than inhaling a Home Run Curry.  It comes with a nice mix of katsu, shrimp tempura, sausage and egg to satisfy all of those cravings.  The wings are slightly dry but extremely crispy and the sauce is delectable.  Prices have definitely increased and portion sizes decreased over the past few years but Go Go Curry still remains one of my favorite spots in NYC for some quick, satisfying comfort food!
Ordered takeout and was disappointed with the food, the curry is on the sweeter side and the pork was very dry.

Got go go curry recently. I ordered the Sausage curry. It's a dish of rice cabbage curry and sausage. It wasn't as great as the go go curry I had ordered from years before. I also only got 3 sausages which is the standard serving size but I think is a bit too little. The curry in its own right was good and I like the new packaging for the to-go order.

Great place to grab lunch. I've tried pretty much everything on the menu at this point and everything is good. If you're hungry or indecisive, I'd go with the homerun curry, which gives you a little bit of everything. Vegetarians also need not fear - there's a tofu katsu and veggie tempura option, but just remember to ask for the vegetarian curry sauce as well (I think their default curry has pork in it). The only issue I run into sometimes is that service can be a bit slow. They seem to be short staffed frequently, often with one guy acting as both cook and cashier, so I've had to wait as long as 20 minutes for take out. Not the end of the world, and the food is ultimately worth it when you get it.

a big ol gorilla size bowl of japanese curry that warms the heart and soul.  on the bottom is a bed of rice.  then you pick your size and your protein.  they have small medium large and xlarge and they measure it by weight.  proteins are chicken or pork katsu, tempura by the piece, shrimp, egg, sausage.  then comes the curry and the cabbage.  they also have some combos where you can try many diff proteins.  the grand slam is a popular one where you can a sample of each.  it can get slow since only one person is working.  its a small place so too many cooks will just be more burdensome than help.  when i crave a quick curry, i come here.  its always consistent and theres multiple locations for wherever you are.

Outstanding Japanese curry comfort food.  Fast service, and the counter woman was mega-efficient and friendly.  There's gotta be a reason for that weird gorilla mascot they've got, but ignore that and just get the katsu and you won't think about that gorilla anymore.  Japanese comfort places aren't as abundant as they should be and so glad I found this place.  Dropping the prices slightly would make it five stars.

Love this quick eats and fast affordable place. Perfect for when youre on the go or even want to have a meal! TThe portions are huge as well as the quality isnt poor! Its flavorful with the loads of curry they ply on. Really love the chicken as the crust was so crispy but the inside so moist. As a college student I appreciate how its so cheap as well as quality is still great! Perfect for cheap eatsand speedy service.

THE PHOTO IS A LIE!!! They changed their containers and the portions are less than half of what it used to be! I used to enjoy their curry, but to get a child size serving for $50 is just ridiculous. Maybe they think we're stupid and willing to pay $50 for mostly shredded cabbage and a small bite of rice. They're being cheap cutting corners and it shows. I was even part of their genki rewards but clearly that's useless now. Disappointed and no longer a customer. I refuse to support a business that's openly ripping off their loyal customers.
No. Just go next door to get food. The pork katsu was bland and the whole bowl of curry/veggies/rice that came with it were a little bland. Just not that satisfying.
Wow this place was great. Wanted to try some Chinatown food and this really hit the spot. Would highly recommend the chicken tonkatsu, comes with cabbage and rice.

I ordered a small pork katsu for lunch and it was delicious! Small means the serving of rice weighs 4 oz. For me, it was just the right amount with the pork cutlet and free cabbage. The sauce was a bit spicy but nothing a medium spice person can't handle. I did ask for extra cabbage to balance out the carbs and they were happy to accommodate. Service is quick but if you're looking to dine in, then definitely try to beat the lunch crowd or have a friend grab seats while you place orders. Overall, not a bad lunch option for the area.

This spot actually has some great curry with plenty of fried options available. The service is really quick and the portions are super filling. I went for the small curry but there was actually a good amount of rice. I added shrimp, pork katsu, chicken katsu and fish katsu on top. The katsu were all pretty thin pieces of meat. The fish in particular was really thin. I preferred the pork and chicken over the fish, which really isn't worth it. The shrimp was also pretty small but covered in plenty of breading. Everything was nice and crispy and the curry was really good too. It wasn't spicy at all. I wish there was just a bit more curry sauce though. I also added pickled radish which is a bit sweet and sour and gave a nice flavor contrast to all the fried items. The cabbage that is provided is also a nice refreshing touch. Definitely an affordable, filling, tasty meal!

I ordered the small with chicken katsu and extra cabbage. If you like spicy, definitely drizzle some on top of the cutlet and you have an amazing lunch for around $10, which is almost unheard of in FiDi.
